ranked_diseases.explanation: Patient presents with 4/5 major features of BBS (retinal dystrophy with myopia/nyctalopia/reduced visual acuity, obesity, intellectual disability). All three reference cases with identical phenotypes were diagnosed with BBS1. Missing polydactyly but this is not present in all BBS patients.
BBS2 presents with similar clinical features as BBS1 including retinal dystrophy, obesity, and intellectual disability. Different genetic cause but phenotypically very similar to BBS1.

Shares obesity, visual impairment (cone-rod dystrophy), and nyctalopia with the patient. However, typically presents with sensorineural hearing loss and cardiomyopathy which are not mentioned. Intellectual disability is less common in Alström.

Features intellectual disability, obesity (truncal), and progressive myopia/night blindness. However, typically includes characteristic facial features, microcephaly, and neutropenia which are not mentioned in this patient.

Historical condition sharing features with BBS including retinal dystrophy, intellectual disability, and obesity. Now often considered part of the BBS spectrum but may represent a distinct entity with additional neurological features.
